required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Postoperative or Salvage Radiotherapy (RT) for Node Negative Prostate Cancer Following Radical Prostatectomy
clinical_study.official_title: Postoperative or Salvage Radiotherapy for Node Negative Prostate Cancer Following Radical Prostatectomy

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to see what effects, good and/or bad, proton radiation, and/or conventional radiation and hormonal therapy (if applicable), has on prostate cancer that has already returned or the risk of prostate cancer returning.

primary_outcome.measure: The treatment-related rate of acute grade 3 gastrointestinal and genitourinary toxicity following treatment with proton based radiation therapy.
primary_outcome.time_frame: 6 months after the end of radiation therapy

secondary_outcome.measure: Collect and analyze quality of life, treatment-related morbidity, disease control and survival outcome parameters
secondary_outcome.time_frame: After radiation: every 6 months for 3 years, then annually for 20 years

arm_group.description: IMRT to 45 Gy; prostate bed proton boost of 21.6 CGE
IMRT to 45 Gy; proton boost to prostate bed to 25.2 CGE

intervention.intervention_name: IMRT to 45 Gy; prostate bed proton boost of 21.6 CGE
IMRT to 45 Gy; proton boost to prostate bed to 25.2 CGE

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Prostate cancer treated primarily with open, laparoscopic or robotically assisted prostatectomy.
- Maximum PSA value of 20 ng/ml.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Evidence of distant metastasis (M1).
- Prior systemic chemotherapy for any reason.
- Previous irradiation to the pelvis that would compromise the ability to deliver the prescribed study treatment.
- Active inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, diverticulitis or ulcerative colitis) affecting the rectum. (Non-active diverticulitis and Crohn's disease not affecting the rectum are allowed).
- History of hip replacement.
- Prior or concurrent cancer, other than non-melanomatous skin cancer, unless disease free for at least 5 years.
- Taking Saw Palmetto or methotrexate and unable or unwilling to discontinue its use during radiation.

overall_official.affiliation: University of Florida Proton Therapy Institute
